bestBHT.bht: The strong man, identified as Satan, wields his dark power over men, armed with various methods. He corrupts the sons of men, but Jesus, the Stronger One, rescues and diverts these spoils for His own use and followers. Through the power of His Gospel, Jesus continually takes from Satan, rescuing and redeeming humanity until the end, when He will bind Satan in the abyss. Jesus's victory over the strong man reveals His authority to liberate and transform humanity from the clutches of evil.

Henry Alford: The strong man is the adversary, Satan; his palace this present world. His goods or tools, or spoils—are the sons of men.
The Stronger than he takes from him, and divides his spoils, turning to His own use and that of His followers all that good which the enemy had corrupted into evil.
He is still taking from him one and another, rescuing the sons of men by the power of His Gospel, till the end, when He shall bind him in the abyss.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Armed—pointing to all the subtle and varied methods by which he wields his dark power over men.
His palace—man whether viewed more largely or in individual souls—how significant of what men are to Satan!
Marvin Vincent: A strong man [ο ισχυρος] . It has the article : the strong man."
Armed [καθωπλισμενος] . Fully armed : down [κατα] from head to heel.

His palace [εαυτου αυλην] . Lit., his own. jAulh is strictly the open court in front of a house : later, the court round which the house is built, and so applied to the house generally, as our door or roof.
Archibald T. Robertson: Fully armed (καθωπλισμενος). Perfect passive participle of καθοπλιζω, an old verb, but here only in the N.T.
His own court (την εαυτου αυλην). His own homestead.
John Gill: By the strong man, is meant the devil... armed both with his own temptations and the sins and lusts of men.
The corrupt heart of an unregenerate man, where he dwells as a king... kept by a guard of devils and worldly lusts.
No concern in such a heart about sin, no uneasiness... but such a man lives in entire security, crying Peace, Peace, to himself.
John Wesley: The strong one armed — The devil, strong in himself, and armed with the pride, obstinacy, and security of him in whom he dwells.

bhtAttempts.bht: The strong man referred to in this verse is Satan, the adversary. Satan's palace is this present world, and his goods are the sons of men, who he has corrupted into evil. However, the Stronger One, Jesus, has come to take from Satan and rescue humanity by the power of His Gospel. He is continuously rescuing people from the clutches of the enemy and turning the corrupted into good. Ultimately, Jesus will bind Satan in the abyss. Satan is fully armed with various methods of wielding his power over men, but Jesus, the Stronger One, is victorious.

The strong man mentioned is Satan, the adversary, who holds sway over this present world. Men are his spoils, corrupted into evil. Yet, the Stronger One, Jesus, diverts the spoils, rescuing humankind through the power of His Gospel. Continuously, He liberates individuals, until the day when Satan will be bound in the abyss. Satan is fully armed, utilizing various methods to exercise his dark power. However, Jesus, the Stronger One, emerges triumphant, turning corrupted goods into good.

Jesus refers to Satan as the strong man, the adversary armed with various methods to wield his dark power over men. Satan's palace represents the corrupt hearts of unregenerate individuals, guarded by devils and worldly lusts. However, Jesus, the Stronger One, takes from Satan, rescuing the sons of men through the power of His Gospel. He turns the corrupted into good and will ultimately bind Satan in the abyss. Jesus's victory over the strong man ensures liberation and deliverance for humanity.

The strong man, identified as Satan, wields his dark power over men, armed with various methods. He corrupts the sons of men, but Jesus, the Stronger One, rescues and diverts these spoils for His own use and followers. Through the power of His Gospel, Jesus continually takes from Satan, rescuing and redeeming humanity until the end, when He will bind Satan in the abyss. Jesus's victory over the strong man reveals His authority to liberate and transform humanity from the clutches of evil.

Jesus confronts the strong man, identified as Satan, who wields his dark power armed with various methods. Satan corrupts the sons of men, but Jesus, the Stronger One, takes from him and rescues humanity through the power of His Gospel. Jesus continues to rescue individuals, reclaiming them from Satan's grip until the end, when He will ultimately bind Satan in the abyss. This victorious act demonstrates Jesus' authority and ability to redeem and deliver humanity from the clutches of evil.
